<span key="9d882249ab6a45d980bfb166f78aa15b"><span offset-key="9d882249ab6a45d980bfb166f78aa15b:0">map is a set of keys, each of which has an associated value. This is not quite the same as a set of key/value pairs.</span></span>

<span key="0480d6abac7c45949ca4bcd28aeadea9"><span offset-key="0480d6abac7c45949ca4bcd28aeadea9:0">use </span>`has()`<span offset-key="0480d6abac7c45949ca4bcd28aeadea9:2"> to check whether a map includes the specified key; use </span>`delete()`<span offset-key="0480d6abac7c45949ca4bcd28aeadea9:4"> to remove a key (and its associated value) from the map; use </span>`clear()`<span offset-key="0480d6abac7c45949ca4bcd28aeadea9:6"> to remove all key/value pairs from the map; and use the size property to find out how many keys a map contains.</span></span>

<span key="3946821ca8de40e9a6186b02f9c2b53d">`set()`<span offset-key="3946821ca8de40e9a6186b02f9c2b53d:1"> method of Map can be chained.</span></span>

<span key="c5025337fa854e73a77d665ace6348fe"><span offset-key="c5025337fa854e73a77d665ace6348fe:0">Any JavaScript value can be used as a key or a value in a Map. This includes</span>` null, undefined`<span offset-key="c5025337fa854e73a77d665ace6348fe:2">, and </span>`NaN`<span offset-key="c5025337fa854e73a77d665ace6348fe:4">, as well as reference types like objects and arrays.</span></span>

<span key="2ce79f14492f417ea96cea080f67f085"><span offset-key="2ce79f14492f417ea96cea080f67f085:0">Map compares keys by identity, not by equality.</span></span>

<span key="824927c4cc9b41fb8dfd176218cbca97">`let m = new Map();`</span>

<span key="893315cf9cb54ed1973fd7dde80ee263">`m.set({}, 1);`</span>

<span key="9c7a68c007fc4745af6ca2de9e992b5d">`m.set({}, 2);`</span>

<span key="ea377b1a013e4e86bd42109232c77cc4"><span offset-key="ea377b1a013e4e86bd42109232c77cc4:0">Map a different empty object to the number 2.</span></span>

<span key="940acbafe313424d8bf66aa71c7c12d6">`m.get({})`</span>

<span key="d1fb3fa1e1184830879fa6b2d55a5c8f"><span offset-key="d1fb3fa1e1184830879fa6b2d55a5c8f:0">undefined:</span></span>

<span key="1b03dabe39d8410bb435e61c1a007fbf">`m.set(m, undefined);`</span>

<span key="f39486daeca843c8b1a4ea0ebd564dea">`m.has(m)`</span>

<span key="c362cd96d8674eeeba362aafeb423d2b"><span offset-key="c362cd96d8674eeeba362aafeb423d2b:0">true</span></span>

<span key="7e48d631a32e47d3ab723a23c03052ad">`m.get(m)`</span>

<span key="3061d03d7ea9428f9381e731cfa15684"><span offset-key="3061d03d7ea9428f9381e731cfa15684:0">undefined</span></span>

<span key="0f3954a45fdb4f6193778ee9bb3cd034"><span offset-key="0f3954a45fdb4f6193778ee9bb3cd034:0">Iterate over map:</span></span>

<span key="a491f4c5c58c4bd690fbafb219aab4cb">`let m = new Map([["x", 1], ["y", 2]]);`</span>

<span key="73f215a33b624b5481fd6264cec9ccb7">`[...m]`</span>

<span key="3364b231e0534a008872c3dd44f5147d"><span offset-key="3364b231e0534a008872c3dd44f5147d:0">\[\[“x”, 1\], \[“y”, 2\]\]</span></span>

<span key="b5f4993f3ce54c63bfdeb961be985077">`for(let [key, value] of m) {...}`</span>

<span key="52a4d2afa05f41408b81d3fceb86e590"><span offset-key="52a4d2afa05f41408b81d3fceb86e590:0">Map class iterates in insertion order</span></span>

<span key="541f42f74c814e989bb3bac1ea148ee8"><span offset-key="541f42f74c814e989bb3bac1ea148ee8:0">If you want to iterate just the keys or just the associated values of a map, use the </span>`keys()`<span offset-key="541f42f74c814e989bb3bac1ea148ee8:2"> and </span>`values()`<span offset-key="541f42f74c814e989bb3bac1ea148ee8:4"> methods: these return iterable objects that iterate keys and values, in insertion order. (The </span>`entries()`<span offset-key="541f42f74c814e989bb3bac1ea148ee8:6"> method returns an iterable object that iterates key/value pairs, but this is exactly the same as iterating the map directly.)</span></span>

5

## 

<span key="c9efddef831849dba1ba5bdef17cb262"><span offset-key="c9efddef831849dba1ba5bdef17cb262:0">WeakMap and WeakSet</span></span>

<span key="e715f0404cf64647af749c9dddb3590e"><span offset-key="e715f0404cf64647af749c9dddb3590e:0">The </span>`WeakMap `<span offset-key="e715f0404cf64647af749c9dddb3590e:2">class is a variant (but not an actual subclass) of the Map class that does not prevent its key values from being garbage collected.</span></span>

<span key="db71e3561a0746c1a41e6ba7f4788d15">`WeakMap `<span offset-key="db71e3561a0746c1a41e6ba7f4788d15:1">keys must be objects or arrays; primitive values are not subject to garbage collection and cannot be used as keys.</span></span>

<span key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd"><span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:0">WeakMap implements only the</span>` get(), set(), has(),`<span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:2"> and </span>`delete()`<span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:4"> methods. In particular, </span>`WeakMap`<span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:6"> is not iterable and does not define </span>`keys(), values(),`<span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:8"> or </span>`forEach()`<span offset-key="b0801e8ae47046fda5154076b523cedd:10">. If WeakMap was iterable, then its keys would be reachable and it wouldn’t be weak.</span></span>

<span key="1de8df05a0fe4b79ad299721dd0c9b90"><span offset-key="1de8df05a0fe4b79ad299721dd0c9b90:0">Similarly, WeakMap does not implement the size property because the </span>`size`<span offset-key="1de8df05a0fe4b79ad299721dd0c9b90:2"> of a WeakMap could change at any time as objects are garbage collected</span></span>

## 

<span key="62ff36a5bf19437d9e1deab7ffc77ac2"><span offset-key="62ff36a5bf19437d9e1deab7ffc77ac2:0">Typed Arrays and Binary Data</span></span>

<span key="46235c9b89be4af0bc6a5026f838506f"><span offset-key="46235c9b89be4af0bc6a5026f838506f:0">They differ from regular arrays in some very important ways</span></span>

<span key="b206c4b6e1f74a0387c8ea0f233f3282"><span offset-key="b206c4b6e1f74a0387c8ea0f233f3282:0">· The elements of a typed array are all numbers. Unlike regular JavaScript numbers, however, typed arrays allow you to specify the type (signed and unsigned integers and IEEE-754 floating point) and size (8 bits to 64 bits) of the numbers to be stored in the array.</span></span>

<span key="68e86400798c430ab2e0d7f35d99a7b6"><span offset-key="68e86400798c430ab2e0d7f35d99a7b6:0">· You must specify the length of a typed array when you create it, and that length can never change.</span></span>

<span key="d524947c735f42fd9158c887dc9eab61"><span offset-key="d524947c735f42fd9158c887dc9eab61:0">· The elements of a typed array are always initialized to 0 when the array is created.</span></span>

<span key="395d4944e24c4a1790b9d34e55fb103f"><span offset-key="395d4944e24c4a1790b9d34e55fb103f:0">Typed arrays are not true arrays, but they re-implement most array methods, so you can use them pretty much just like you’d use regular arrays:</span></span>

<span key="26211e54f718438baf36872aa012f10d">`let ints = new Int16Array(10);`</span>

<span key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc"><span offset-key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc:0">Remember that typed arrays have fixed lengths, so the length property is read-only, and methods that change the length of the array (such as</span>` push(), pop(), unshift(), shift(),`<span offset-key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc:2"> and </span>`splice()`<span offset-key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc:4">) are not implemented for typed arrays. Methods that alter the contents of an array without changing the length (such as </span>`sort(), reverse()`<span offset-key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc:6">, and </span>`fill()`<span offset-key="8741f32ca0f448d89f48663b6aa124dc:8">) are implemented.</span></span>

1

<span key="0cdc818c947440c3b5543a10dc9d9b8e"><span offset-key="0cdc818c947440c3b5543a10dc9d9b8e:0">let pattern = /s$/;</span></span>

<span key="61f02ef6f3c54776ac1edf89a2ee1605"><span offset-key="61f02ef6f3c54776ac1edf89a2ee1605:0">Regular expressions can also have one or more flag characters that affect how they work</span></span>

1

<span key="9f079fdbc9524e99bfd5cc3911f61e3b"><span offset-key="9f079fdbc9524e99bfd5cc3911f61e3b:0">let pattern = /s$/i;</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="8e16d75ec14e41caa7a5fd153c73eedc"><span offset-key="8e16d75ec14e41caa7a5fd153c73eedc:0">i = case insensitive</span></span>

<span key="e16f604ce96846afa9a89165e2453bf0"><span offset-key="e16f604ce96846afa9a89165e2453bf0:0">Punctuation characters have special meanings in regular expressions: </span>`^ $ . * + ? = ! : | \ / ( ) [ ] { }. `<span offset-key="e16f604ce96846afa9a89165e2453bf0:2">Other punctuation characters, such as quotation marks and @, do not have special meaning and simply match themselves literally in a regular expression.</span></span>

<span key="ae035db70b2f457792f89af5fe461bc1"><span offset-key="ae035db70b2f457792f89af5fe461bc1:0">If you use the </span>`RegExp()`<span offset-key="ae035db70b2f457792f89af5fe461bc1:2"> constructor, keep in mind that any backslashes in your regular expression need to be doubled, since strings also use backslashes as an escape character.</span></span>

<span key="388a9aa372c94410a4bf3c0ddceca5d0">**Character**</span>

<span key="e806c782b02a4177b02d1b88a6d81de1">**Matches**</span>

<span key="323fb572b43e4181bddc7d386b52ead3">`[...]`</span>

<span key="06fc41f16c434a53940b43852f00faca"><span offset-key="06fc41f16c434a53940b43852f00faca:0">Any one character between the brackets.</span></span>

<span key="d6e1401fc8234eee86b5fb8389c658b4">`[^...]`</span>

<span key="13f143f57af74aa98565edfaa0d49fdd"><span offset-key="13f143f57af74aa98565edfaa0d49fdd:0">Any one character not between the brackets</span></span>

<span key="01746dcf0ad544d7b886905b560afa21">`.`</span>

<span key="3c388c4136df4a33a56117c4f68fd63e"><span offset-key="3c388c4136df4a33a56117c4f68fd63e:0">Any character except newline or another Unicode line terminator. Or, if the </span>`RegExp`<span offset-key="3c388c4136df4a33a56117c4f68fd63e:2"> uses the s flag, then a period matches any character, including line terminators.</span></span>

<span key="5e1fbed3f5bc4938ba2867b0fc7899f9">`\w`</span>

<span key="e635a32c916345fd80a59260a0ed6bd1"><span offset-key="e635a32c916345fd80a59260a0ed6bd1:0">Any ASCII word character. Equivalent to \[a-zA-Z0–9\_\].</span></span>

<span key="c02abd3506444892a55928db70e0f3e6">`\W`</span>

<span key="1b8833edc3034268b7f26ac17fe3b57f"><span offset-key="1b8833edc3034268b7f26ac17fe3b57f:0">Equivalent to \[^a-zA-Z0–9\_\]</span></span>

<span key="34b65709b5c8450db62309a0ec665afb">`\s`</span>

<span key="abac16d27c3c4a2f9f0a57a04704f1d5"><span offset-key="abac16d27c3c4a2f9f0a57a04704f1d5:0">Any Unicode whitespace character.</span></span>

<span key="f3da2dc894f74d00a7c30beed5a12f2a">`\S`</span>

<span key="86794d11a83a4052a62c05cd81c7d13d"><span offset-key="86794d11a83a4052a62c05cd81c7d13d:0">Any character that is not Unicode whitespace.</span></span>

<span key="7f8de7f1cbbc4f07aba1780379548af4">`\d`</span>

<span key="86b8b2d0590f4fa8942f2ab2e4b75c02"><span offset-key="86b8b2d0590f4fa8942f2ab2e4b75c02:0">Equivalent to \[0–9\].</span></span>

<span key="703e2f0e70ec4b74b44679b010b2a6f5">`\D`</span>

<span key="71f703a0aa054d489305dad758e25f1e"><span offset-key="71f703a0aa054d489305dad758e25f1e:0">Equivalent to \[⁰-9\].</span></span>

<span key="fda1b63014044cd19613253988ee2b34">`[\b]`</span>

<span key="e6e4b9ef24f34de2a25ba48d5828c9f1"><span offset-key="e6e4b9ef24f34de2a25ba48d5828c9f1:0">A literal backspace (special case).</span></span>

<span key="78539abd3b33482eb42f751729892f6e">`[\s\d]`</span>

<span key="11b99554a45e468d9c8ccebedf54f2e9"><span offset-key="11b99554a45e468d9c8ccebedf54f2e9:0">Any one whitespace character or digit</span></span>

<span key="1d4eaa3204474486bf0b50cc769ff360"><span offset-key="1d4eaa3204474486bf0b50cc769ff360:0">REPETITIONS</span></span>

<span key="ec020f5cc9f945b0b6f04586186705e6">**Character**</span>

<span key="ad41d0e5fcc240139e63e78bcaa57481">**Meaning**</span>

<span key="e9e00e52266644a9a5dd95cc792a0b83">`{n,m}`</span>

<span key="7bac945fc6624fdfb211aafe3a4e50a7"><span offset-key="7bac945fc6624fdfb211aafe3a4e50a7:0">Match the previous item at least n times but no more than m times</span></span>

<span key="261145ea7908493ea5d85016dbb2f49f">`{n,}`</span>

<span key="588fa5aa943c49a3916865605c67cf89"><span offset-key="588fa5aa943c49a3916865605c67cf89:0">Match the previous item n or more times.</span></span>

<span key="3c5a6af1744644fa862fd428e63be431">`{n}`</span>

<span key="bd665b1a5e9f461997a0641696b4b6f2"><span offset-key="bd665b1a5e9f461997a0641696b4b6f2:0">Match exactly n occurrences of the previous item.</span></span>

<span key="8b5d0a3a11e74512bd649164675c460e">`?`</span>

<span key="ad0d0ff5e2284c429342fffef6106fe4"><span offset-key="ad0d0ff5e2284c429342fffef6106fe4:0">Equivalent to {0,1}.</span></span>

<span key="0ed0c889de67472a9c2231de29233f8c">`+`</span>

<span key="205e98a193c3447d987b4be7a0d37d55"><span offset-key="205e98a193c3447d987b4be7a0d37d55:0">Equivalent to {1,}</span></span>

<span key="0932e2876ff844b1978693615fa7f5b0"><span offset-key="0932e2876ff844b1978693615fa7f5b0:0">\*</span></span>

<span key="ebf626aa4443487f8bfee15acffc303b"><span offset-key="ebf626aa4443487f8bfee15acffc303b:0">Equivalent to {0,}.</span></span>

<span key="386a491d6b28441db62d12e0d1f9b039">**Example**</span>

<span key="699421ad39a843abbdeaff5bf031e904">**Description**</span>

1

<span key="daef829d14804b4687c7b671059b582f"><span offset-key="daef829d14804b4687c7b671059b582f:0">let r = /\\d{2,4}/;</span></span>

## 

<span key="1c2456a66ea44a7a9ee134105d3f6a14"><span offset-key="1c2456a66ea44a7a9ee134105d3f6a14:0">ALTERNATION, GROUPING, AND REFERENCES</span></span>

<span key="c4cb6c559dea424b9fd8465589289fcb">**Char**</span>

<span key="1c37e6d3139e44bfa1d8b12436e45d9e">**Pattern**</span>

<span key="282a0084b22e4abba1daa78e137f65a1">**Pattern**</span>

<span key="b33e36c99b7d43ab96e8abc7bba56136">`|`</span>

<span key="905651b8ff3e407a84904059d82c8eb6">`/ab|cd|ef/`</span>

<span key="6636fa8b12b346a0a125a21bc203befe"><span offset-key="6636fa8b12b346a0a125a21bc203befe:0">“ab” or the string “cd” or the string “ef”.</span></span>

<span key="184e196f667d45ea802960f012baea7e">`/\d{3}|[a-z]{4}/`</span>

<span key="9c6c7caa539c495ca87aa9121ebbecbd"><span offset-key="9c6c7caa539c495ca87aa9121ebbecbd:0">either three digits or four lowercase letters.</span></span>

<span key="e93139b097e2483a905543178199e83f">`/a|ab/`</span>

<span key="3af718cc9a1a43b1ad6cdda6a69f2fe8"><span offset-key="3af718cc9a1a43b1ad6cdda6a69f2fe8:0">matches only the first letter “a”</span></span>

<span key="1fca4d28736341d89b2bc3e1bc56973f">`()`</span>

<span key="1ecba19c469b4888aae6442a27db13d0">`/java(script)?/`</span>

<span key="bf8f3f197dd246d9b3b58f5b3164585f"><span offset-key="bf8f3f197dd246d9b3b58f5b3164585f:0">matches “java” followed by the optional “script”</span></span>

<span key="0713b8dd120c4f75bc66a9c1719e7459">`/(ab|cd)+|ef/`</span>

<span key="0ace92f3bfef4561ae9f26e3ca438fcc"><span offset-key="0ace92f3bfef4561ae9f26e3ca438fcc:0">matches “java” followed by the optional “script”</span></span>

<span key="9b3d36870d114f68b0b0d4d7a8e73b9a"><span offset-key="9b3d36870d114f68b0b0d4d7a8e73b9a:0">If the left alternative matches, the right alternative is ignored, even if it would have produced a “better” match</span></span>

<span key="f0742464e6a34ebdb1b7f5fa74135477"><span offset-key="f0742464e6a34ebdb1b7f5fa74135477:0">Another purpose of parentheses in regular expressions is to define subpatterns within the complete pattern. When a regular expression is successfully matched against a target string, it is possible to extract the portions of the target string that matched any particular parenthesized subpattern. For example, suppose you are looking for one or more lowercase letters followed by one or more digits. You might use the pattern </span>`/[a-z]+\d+/`<span offset-key="f0742464e6a34ebdb1b7f5fa74135477:2">. But suppose you only really care about the digits at the end of each match. If you put that part of the pattern in parentheses (/\[a-z\]+(\\d+)/), you can extract the digits from any matches you find,</span></span>

<span key="793f201c3ae046308426e56becf56d1f"><span offset-key="793f201c3ae046308426e56becf56d1f:0">A related use of parenthesized subexpressions is to allow you to refer back to a subexpression later in the same regular expression. This is done by following a \\ character by a digit or digits. The digits refer to the position of the parenthesized subexpression within the regular expression. For example, \\1 refers back to the first subexpression, and \\3 refers to the third.</span></span>

<span key="ecaf661008d9438e863cde9aa27dc723">**Match**</span>

<span key="eea18b096e4445e78a356faec12d79b5">**Pattern**</span>

<span key="63cc4148ce9c4f36a69b853a2abd817a"><span offset-key="63cc4148ce9c4f36a69b853a2abd817a:0">zero or more characters within single or double quotes. However, it does not require the opening and closing quotes to match</span></span>

<span key="ebfad3eda00d4253a1626f01a8b8ec02">**Character**</span>

<span key="da584ffb801f4f0b9b2980437940d690">**Meaning**</span>

<span key="61d066a7eb7b4619b5d10974f2c4541d"><span offset-key="61d066a7eb7b4619b5d10974f2c4541d:0">|</span></span>

<span key="e4b94640adf34a6691a87693fa52d8d8"><span offset-key="e4b94640adf34a6691a87693fa52d8d8:0">match either the subexpression to the left or the subexpression to the right.</span></span>

<span key="d2e3452528a54abc98b423eaad505041"><span offset-key="d2e3452528a54abc98b423eaad505041:0">(…)</span></span>

<span key="335766d1976942f5808ecf7daa8ba386"><span offset-key="335766d1976942f5808ecf7daa8ba386:0">Grouping: group items into a single unit that can be used with \*, +, ?, |, and so on. Also remember the characters that match this group for use with later references</span></span>

<span key="f20593ccc7664098be8a9e36fc4ca0b9"><span offset-key="f20593ccc7664098be8a9e36fc4ca0b9:0">(?:…)</span></span>

<span key="1e9975bfc6cf42489c36cb4da2265a5b"><span offset-key="1e9975bfc6cf42489c36cb4da2265a5b:0">group items into a single unit, but do not remember the characters that match this group.</span></span>

<span key="997b13d790d348db9fc3d561b799d089"><span offset-key="997b13d790d348db9fc3d561b799d089:0">Note</span>` (?:...)`<span offset-key="997b13d790d348db9fc3d561b799d089:2"> syntax:</span></span>

<span key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e"><span offset-key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e:0">In pattern</span>` "/([Jj]ava(?:[Ss]cript)?)\sis\s(fun\w*)/`<span offset-key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e:2">" </span>`\2`<span offset-key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e:4"> refers to the text matched by </span>`(fun\w*)`<span offset-key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e:6"> since </span>`(?:[Ss]cript)?)`<span offset-key="23de20667a064c76a02ba6638692cd5e:8"> in not remembered.</span></span>

## 

<span key="133aa4d30adf492b948feee312a8ec0f"><span offset-key="133aa4d30adf492b948feee312a8ec0f:0">SPECIFYING MATCH POSITION</span></span>

<span key="8bac0f3cfa3c4e0b889873fff71f3651">*regular expression anchors*<span offset-key="8bac0f3cfa3c4e0b889873fff71f3651:1"> because they anchor the pattern to a specific position in the search string. The most commonly used anchor elements are ^, which ties the pattern to the beginning of the string, and $, which anchors the pattern to the end of the string.</span></span>

<span key="e88f7c8d38584979b7bac4dd3017f006">**Example**</span>

<span key="cdebac2be0ae47b98fb73e98fc69b8b8">**Pattern**</span>

<span key="bcddd85020294b429e45754e129e703d"><span offset-key="bcddd85020294b429e45754e129e703d:0">match the word “JavaScript” on a line by itself</span></span>

<span key="db1221115fb04d7280938b8d89803d09">`/^JavaScript$/`</span>

<span key="a486791b58c14e2a84bcf8499989a435"><span offset-key="a486791b58c14e2a84bcf8499989a435:0">To search for “Java” as a word by itself you can try the pattern </span>`/\sJava\s/`<span offset-key="a486791b58c14e2a84bcf8499989a435:2">, which requires a space before and after the word. But there are two problems with this solution. First, it does not match "Java" at the beginning or the end of a string, but only if it appears with space on either side. Second, when this pattern does find a match, the matched string it returns has leading and trailing spaces, which is not quite what’s needed. So instead of matching actual space characters with \\s, match (or anchor to) word boundaries with \\b. The resulting expression is </span>`/\bJava\b/`<span offset-key="a486791b58c14e2a84bcf8499989a435:4">.</span></span>

<span key="83dd02902e1c4f7da2d28e157adb3fbe"><span offset-key="83dd02902e1c4f7da2d28e157adb3fbe:0">The element </span>`\B`<span offset-key="83dd02902e1c4f7da2d28e157adb3fbe:2"> anchors the match to a location that is not a word boundary. Thus, the pattern </span>`/\B[Ss]cript/`<span offset-key="83dd02902e1c4f7da2d28e157adb3fbe:4"> matches "JavaScript" and "postscript", but not "script" or "Scripting".</span></span>

<span key="de097764fcd34f4d886bc9439a21376a"><span offset-key="de097764fcd34f4d886bc9439a21376a:0">You can also use arbitrary regular expressions as anchor conditions.</span></span>

<span key="d948eed6a16e45f5beac7aa6ee9cb21a"><span offset-key="d948eed6a16e45f5beac7aa6ee9cb21a:0">If you include an expression within </span>`(?= and )`<span offset-key="d948eed6a16e45f5beac7aa6ee9cb21a:2"> characters, it is a lookahead assertion, and it specifies that the enclosed characters must match, without actually matching them.</span></span>

<span key="b7694a1f073c443496d32a306f82850f">**Example**</span>

<span key="bc0b43e7d6c34bffaf922e96c5ecef29">**Pattern**</span>

<span key="1d596d70a6bd4ea5b6a8aaaf026d377f">**Matches**</span>

<span key="63e840e9672947fdb4195c9886c9f663"><span offset-key="63e840e9672947fdb4195c9886c9f663:0">to match the name of a common programming language, but only if it is followed by a colon</span></span>

<span key="3b677461554c499a9d1626e7bb568188">`/[Jj]ava([Ss]cript)?(?=\:)/`</span>

<span key="26ff1535c32a4cd3b0f724585dc28647"><span offset-key="26ff1535c32a4cd3b0f724585dc28647:0">matches the word “JavaScript” in “JavaScript: The DefinitiveGuide”</span></span>

<span key="cf9d88f3d0804be989c0d858174864d0"><span offset-key="cf9d88f3d0804be989c0d858174864d0:0">does not match “Java” in “Java in a Nutshell”</span></span>

<span key="3b601e4f71674987bb4d751970f12a79"><span offset-key="3b601e4f71674987bb4d751970f12a79:0">If you instead introduce an assertion with </span>`(?!`<span offset-key="3b601e4f71674987bb4d751970f12a79:2">, it is a negative lookahead assertion.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f10c187a36584a76bd3901aea6fb71c7"><span offset-key="f10c187a36584a76bd3901aea6fb71c7:0">FLAGS</span></span>

<span key="90773057022041e9a983439f38c32459"><span offset-key="90773057022041e9a983439f38c32459:0">Flags are specified after the second / character of a regular expression literal or as a string passed as the second argument to the RegExp() constructor.</span></span>

<span key="6821436042d044a693b22ffd28f3f1e3">**Flag**</span>

<span key="b4f42be915974cda952acc139eeaa122">**Meaning**</span>

<span key="39180690b0594daba5dc7b97a0c12d1f"><span offset-key="39180690b0594daba5dc7b97a0c12d1f:0">g</span></span>

<span key="f8e681bff1bb4f5e908b141c4e762deb"><span offset-key="f8e681bff1bb4f5e908b141c4e762deb:0">“global” — that is,that we intend to use it to find all matches within a string rather than just finding the first </span></span><a href="http://match.it" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2fe10b7312e54cc7871bc45dc89550d9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-58691_259-58692-237__"><span data-key="67a42a95c822443f84a4f717830d3ae2"><span data-offset-key="67a42a95c822443f84a4f717830d3ae2:0">match.it</span></span></span></a><span key="37a26618048c4c768e1677c2386ca00d"><span offset-key="37a26618048c4c768e1677c2386ca00d:0"> does alter the behavior of the String </span>`match()`<span offset-key="37a26618048c4c768e1677c2386ca00d:2"> method and the </span>`RegExp exec()`<span offset-key="37a26618048c4c768e1677c2386ca00d:4"> method in important ways.</span></span>

<span key="42556b1564504f53b15121ca01bde3a7"><span offset-key="42556b1564504f53b15121ca01bde3a7:0">i</span></span>

<span key="0f2bb4565bbc4259ab50c4d051f60ce4"><span offset-key="0f2bb4565bbc4259ab50c4d051f60ce4:0">case-insensitive</span></span>

<span key="7da4235da0ab4047861599abe081d6cf"><span offset-key="7da4235da0ab4047861599abe081d6cf:0">m</span></span>

<span key="80f4ed2222c244789bc2a14e530968e3"><span offset-key="80f4ed2222c244789bc2a14e530968e3:0">“multiline” mode</span></span>

<span key="a4dae39e695d42f9a5b071850b9bcfdf"><span offset-key="a4dae39e695d42f9a5b071850b9bcfdf:0">s</span></span>

<span key="206370b879b74f1eb11e0fb4380bbd1f"><span offset-key="206370b879b74f1eb11e0fb4380bbd1f:0">useful when working with text that includes newlines.Normally, a “.” in a regular expression matches any character except a line terminator. When the s flag is used, however, “.” will match any character, including line terminators.</span></span>

<span key="8dd839aac64a45549e69483e63d10619"><span offset-key="8dd839aac64a45549e69483e63d10619:0">u</span></span>

<span key="cb8534b300d64669b3b54957925c8b25"><span offset-key="cb8534b300d64669b3b54957925c8b25:0">Unicode.</span></span>

<span key="463558f1800e47f094a41fd4f13305b0"><span offset-key="463558f1800e47f094a41fd4f13305b0:0">Setting the u flag on a RegExp also allows you to use the new </span>`\u{...}`<span offset-key="463558f1800e47f094a41fd4f13305b0:2"> escape sequence for Unicode character and also enables the \\p{...} notation for Unicode character classes.</span></span>

<span key="6573a25315f24ecd994f1e00b02e7cbe"><span offset-key="6573a25315f24ecd994f1e00b02e7cbe:0">y</span></span>

<span key="2ae8a3cf58664e9086caef14fb295f18"><span offset-key="2ae8a3cf58664e9086caef14fb295f18:0">“sticky”. should match at the beginning of a string or at the first character following the previous match</span></span>

## 

<span key="a4f9db30cf3c4ffaad636383a857bc70"><span offset-key="a4f9db30cf3c4ffaad636383a857bc70:0">String Methods for Pattern Matching</span></span>

## 

<span key="9ee28cc4a5f64fb78d5cefc7cb52f7e4"><span offset-key="9ee28cc4a5f64fb78d5cefc7cb52f7e4:0">SEARCH()</span></span>

<span key="5e4d18a885b443f1a4b86a1a28a1de6f"><span offset-key="5e4d18a885b443f1a4b86a1a28a1de6f:0">Strings support four methods that use regular expressions.</span></span>

<span key="13f85e718de947e4aee7d2a535fc9194">`"JavaScript".search(/script/ui)`</span>

<span key="b87912b7578142778d778456ed52d7f8"><span offset-key="b87912b7578142778d778456ed52d7f8:0">4</span></span>

<span key="2a54c5e16c0c4f38a1bca010f617aa36">`"Python".search(/script/ui)`</span>

<span key="74fcfe967b6549efaf78b3ea4b68e287"><span offset-key="74fcfe967b6549efaf78b3ea4b68e287:0">-1</span></span>

<span key="bb258c44be1649a186bfae5666769cd5">`search()`<span offset-key="bb258c44be1649a186bfae5666769cd5:1"> does not support global searches; it ignores the </span>`g`<span offset-key="bb258c44be1649a186bfae5666769cd5:3"> flag of its regular expression argument.</span></span>

<span key="e3e140be486748c9b88fd350cfff1862"><span offset-key="e3e140be486748c9b88fd350cfff1862:0">REPLACE()</span></span>

<span key="0cb086c81e5a4f9897e360b1d73719c5">`text.replace(/javascript/gi, "JavaScript");`</span>

<span key="d0f2df2806994bbd94efcc10d693d978"><span offset-key="d0f2df2806994bbd94efcc10d693d978:0">No matter how it is capitalized, replace it with the correct capitalization</span></span>

<span key="7dc63d0f18c14bdc864361cf2cdcd06c"><span offset-key="7dc63d0f18c14bdc864361cf2cdcd06c:0">parenthesized subexpressions of a regular expression are numbered from left to right and that the regular expression remembers the text that each subexpression matches.</span></span>

<span key="b4e094a3f8bb440aab8f6617bf4bad80"><span offset-key="b4e094a3f8bb440aab8f6617bf4bad80:0">to replace quotation marks in a string with other characters:</span></span>

<span key="7cb826d08da14082afe3c8cb44e58049">`let quote = /"([^"]*)"/g;`</span>

<span key="38e9809d9ec14fd2bf6e14bf5ed97deb">`'He said "stop"'.replace(quote, '«$1»')`</span>

<span key="5f861ee1c83a48e7ac31c54277e0a5aa"><span offset-key="5f861ee1c83a48e7ac31c54277e0a5aa:0">‘He said «stop»’</span></span>

<span key="f7ad0c9b4b3247efb614e25c7ad26bd4"><span offset-key="f7ad0c9b4b3247efb614e25c7ad26bd4:0">If your RegExp uses named capture groups, then you can refer to the matching text by name rather than by number:</span></span>

<span key="6ce6224bf5cc4489aa344eee01f3ef2c">`let quote = /"(?<quotedText>[^"]*)"/g;`</span>

<span key="159bc1a1e37546e4a431669dd4bae362"><span offset-key="159bc1a1e37546e4a431669dd4bae362:0">Instead of passing a replacement string as the second argument to replace(), you can also pass a function that will be invoked to compute the replacement value.</span></span>

<span key="3cc1ac0307f347769faa822c65f365d7"><span offset-key="3cc1ac0307f347769faa822c65f365d7:0">Example to convert decimal integers in a string to hexadecimal:</span></span>

For each iteration of the loop, we’re creating a new RegExp object with </span>`lastIndex`<span offset-key="90d9c1f447ab498a94749adb451d63a4:2"> set to 0, so </span>`exec()`<span offset-key="90d9c1f447ab498a94749adb451d63a4:4"> always begins at the start of the string, and if there is a match, it will keep matching over and over. The solution, of course, is to define the RegExp once, and save it to a variable so that we’re using the same RegExp object for each iteration of the loop.</span></span>

<span key="b768f4b17ecd4af498361fa14b0c4e32"><span offset-key="b768f4b17ecd4af498361fa14b0c4e32:0">On the other hand, sometimes reusing a RegExp object is the wrong thing to do. <span key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82"><span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:0">Because we set the g flag on the RegExp, the </span>`lastIndex`<span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:2"> property is changed after successful matches, and the </span>`test()`<span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:4"> method (which is based on </span>`exec()`<span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:6">) starts searching for a match at the position specified by </span>`lastIndex`<span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:8">. After matching the "pp" in "apple", </span>`lastIndex`<span offset-key="f6e727b00168465c9416d68d5e154e82:10"> is 3, and so we start searching the word "book" at position 3 and do not see the "oo" that it contains.</span></span>

<span key="cdc4907367d744dbab0178bb3d11826f"><span offset-key="cdc4907367d744dbab0178bb3d11826f:0">If you print a date (with console.log(century), for example), it will, by default, be printed in your local time zone. If you want to display a date in UTC, you should explicitly convert it to a string with </span>`toUTCString()`<span offset-key="cdc4907367d744dbab0178bb3d11826f:2"> or</span>` toISOString()`<span offset-key="cdc4907367d744dbab0178bb3d11826f:4">.</span></span>

<span key="cdda25ff784d4adca3df07f884a4cc14">`let century = new Date("2100-01-01T00:00:00Z");`</span>

<span key="3c946c439a7b4367a7872ef29a7344b4"><span offset-key="3c946c439a7b4367a7872ef29a7344b4:0">Once you have a Date object, various get and set methods allow you to query and modify the year, month, day-of-month, hour, minute, second, and millisecond fields of the Date. Each of these methods hastwo forms: one that gets or sets using local time and one that gets or sets using UTC time.</span></span>

<span key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514"><span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:0">Note that the methods for querying the day-of-month are </span>`getDate()`<span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:2"> and </span>`getUTCDate()`<span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:4">. The more natural-sounding functions </span>`getDay()`<span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:6"> and </span>`getUTCDay()`<span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:8"> return the day-of-week (0 for Sunday through 6 for Saturday). The day-of-week is read-only, so there is not a corresponding </span>`setDay()`<span offset-key="c77dcb49f6184a41bb8b4acb18f33514:10"> method.</span></span>

<span key="0c80cbb4d5ff43d49a12bc1c5fb2d89b"><span offset-key="0c80cbb4d5ff43d49a12bc1c5fb2d89b:0">Error Classes</span></span>

<span key="c69ccbd7035d47539619b6e2e886454b"><span offset-key="c69ccbd7035d47539619b6e2e886454b:0">One good reason to use an Error object is that, when you create an Error, it captures the state of the JavaScript stack, and if the exception is uncaught, the stack trace will be displayed with the error message, which will help you debug the issue.</span></span>

<span key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb"><span offset-key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb:0">Error objects have two properties: </span>`message`<span offset-key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb:2"> and </span>`name`<span offset-key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb:4">, and a</span>` toString()`<span offset-key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb:6"> method. Node and all modern browsers also define a </span>`stack`<span offset-key="08cc5fb9f9ee4327840ab2657ed741cb:8"> property on Error objects.</span></span>

<span key="09740e679aca44529154408bda1efb7c"><span offset-key="09740e679aca44529154408bda1efb7c:0">Subclasses are </span>`EvalError, RangeError, ReferenceError, SyntaxError, TypeError,`<span offset-key="09740e679aca44529154408bda1efb7c:2"> and </span>`URIError`<span offset-key="09740e679aca44529154408bda1efb7c:4">.</span></span>

<span key="7b8b365968ea4e1596c054254ca86217"><span offset-key="7b8b365968ea4e1596c054254ca86217:0">You should feel free to define your own Error subclasses that best encapsulate the error conditions of your own program.</span></span>

<span key="ff4ada1157064f4781dbb0c02973e9d1"><span offset-key="ff4ada1157064f4781dbb0c02973e9d1:0">Typically, you pass only a single argument to </span>`JSON.stringify()`<span offset-key="ff4ada1157064f4781dbb0c02973e9d1:2"> and </span>`JSON.parse()`<span offset-key="ff4ada1157064f4781dbb0c02973e9d1:4">. Both functions accept an optional second argument that allows us to extend the JSON format.</span></span>

<span key="e23e9449aac048afae46b25c68f9fa1f">`JSON.stringify()`<span offset-key="e23e9449aac048afae46b25c68f9fa1f:1"> also takes an optional third argument. If you would like your JSONformatted string to be human-readable (if it is being used as a configuration file, for example), then you should pass null as the second argument and pass a number or string as the third argument. If the third argument is a number, then it will use that number of spaces for each indentation level. If the third argument is a string of whitespace (such as '\\t'), it will use that string for each level of indent.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f4da45f4e6a94f92a9f94bcc8562e6b1"><span offset-key="f4da45f4e6a94f92a9f94bcc8562e6b1:0">The Console API</span></span>

<span key="655c90bb19de4bd2b26a6c391e89dfae"><span offset-key="655c90bb19de4bd2b26a6c391e89dfae:0">Console functions that print their arguments like console.log() have a little-known feature: if the first argument is a string that includes </span>`%s, %i, %d, %f, %o, %O, or %c`<span offset-key="655c90bb19de4bd2b26a6c391e89dfae:2">, then this first argument is treated as format string, and the values of subsequent arguments are substituted into the string in place of the two-character % sequences.</span></span>

## 

<span key="5daa67a98b114b88b29cc9f565453e35"><span offset-key="5daa67a98b114b88b29cc9f565453e35:0">Generators</span></span>

<span key="67d531d9562e4388854b4b1c3c36e484"><span offset-key="67d531d9562e4388854b4b1c3c36e484:0">Particularly useful when the values to be iterated are not the elements of a data structure, but the result of a computation.</span></span>

<span key="2cf6e6e33117480eb1f3b01acf2103c6"><span offset-key="2cf6e6e33117480eb1f3b01acf2103c6:0">To create a generator, you must first define a generator function — defined with the keyword </span>`function*`<span offset-key="2cf6e6e33117480eb1f3b01acf2103c6:2"> rather than </span>`function`</span>

<span key="7a6532c58678422ea96e61aec016b397"><span offset-key="7a6532c58678422ea96e61aec016b397:0">When you invoke a generator function, it does not actually execute the function body, but instead returns a generator object. This generator object is an iterator.</span></span>

<span key="609784ccbf8a411196993c7576000459"><span offset-key="609784ccbf8a411196993c7576000459:0">Calling its </span>`next()`<span offset-key="609784ccbf8a411196993c7576000459:2"> method causes the body of the generator function to run from the start (or whatever its current position is) until it reaches a </span>`yield`<span offset-key="609784ccbf8a411196993c7576000459:4"> statement.</span></span>

<span key="43a5fe168ed845efb70d182676cdce4f"><span offset-key="43a5fe168ed845efb70d182676cdce4f:0">The value of the </span>`yield`<span offset-key="43a5fe168ed845efb70d182676cdce4f:2"> statement becomes the value returned by the </span>`next()`<span offset-key="43a5fe168ed845efb70d182676cdce4f:4"> call on the iterator.</span></span>

## 

<span key="97a0f358cbb0487795dd4f826a854e9d"><span offset-key="97a0f358cbb0487795dd4f826a854e9d:0">Asynchronous Javascript</span></span>

<span key="2862f507fe234e77bb6bd986f8b01b29">`Promises`<span offset-key="2862f507fe234e77bb6bd986f8b01b29:1">, new in ES6, are objects that represent the not-yet-available result of an asynchronous operation.</span></span>

<span key="4cad428e47fc4124ae19e0225f0a7690"><span offset-key="4cad428e47fc4124ae19e0225f0a7690:0">The keywords </span>`async`<span offset-key="4cad428e47fc4124ae19e0225f0a7690:2"> and </span>`await`<span offset-key="4cad428e47fc4124ae19e0225f0a7690:4"> were introduced in ES2017 and provide new syntax that simplifies asynchronous programming by allowing you to structure your Promise based code as if it was synchronous.</span></span>

<span key="4ccae56e237b457fa714f5beee77d0b2"><span offset-key="4ccae56e237b457fa714f5beee77d0b2:0">Asynchronous iterators and the</span>` for/await`<span offset-key="4ccae56e237b457fa714f5beee77d0b2:2"> loop were introduced in ES2018 and allow you to work with streams of asynchronous events using simple loops that appear synchronous.</span></span>

## 

<span key="14ab308f586a47248bb129b0e43bc4e6"><span offset-key="14ab308f586a47248bb129b0e43bc4e6:0">Promises</span></span>

<span key="8eb5cf6f4f8847909c5ec645735f9650"><span offset-key="8eb5cf6f4f8847909c5ec645735f9650:0">Promises, a core language feature designed to simplify asynchronous programming.</span></span>

<span key="f7373dd1a9c64187ab5d015d34aecf79"><span offset-key="f7373dd1a9c64187ab5d015d34aecf79:0">A Promise is an object that represents the result of an asynchronous computation. That result may or may not be ready yet, and the Promise API is intentionally vague about this: there is no way to synchronously get the value of a Promise; you can only ask the Promise to call a callback function when the value is ready.</span></span>

<span key="921665fe9d5e4717bd4e00cf540dc763"><span offset-key="921665fe9d5e4717bd4e00cf540dc763:0">One real problem with callback-based asynchronous programming is that it is common to end up with callbacks inside callbacks inside callbacks, with lines of code so highly indented that it is difficult to read.</span></span>

<span key="830a1015ed4e4f1ebb7adb4fc9271431"><span offset-key="830a1015ed4e4f1ebb7adb4fc9271431:0">Promises allow this kind of nested callback to be re-expressed as a more linear Promise chain that tends to be easier to read and easier to reason about.</span></span>

<span key="d2c24abbbb8d4aedaa42b8b11035f17d"><span offset-key="d2c24abbbb8d4aedaa42b8b11035f17d:0">Another problem with callbacks is that they can make handling errors difficult. If an asynchronous function (or an asynchronously invoked callback) throws an exception, there is no way for that exception to propagate back to the initiator of the asynchronous operation. This is a fundamental fact about asynchronous programming: it breaks exception handling. Promises help here by standardizing a way to handle errors and providing a way for errors to propagate correctly through a chain of promises.</span></span>

<span key="b29f41768e6f4ac8b3dc4fe664415d3a"><span offset-key="b29f41768e6f4ac8b3dc4fe664415d3a:0">Note that Promises represent the future results of single asynchronous computations. They cannot be used to represent repeated asynchronous computations, however.</span></span>

<span key="0e36a037b5824906a2ef810ef0f8422e"><span offset-key="0e36a037b5824906a2ef810ef0f8422e:0">We can’t use Promises to replace </span>`setInterval()`<span offset-key="0e36a037b5824906a2ef810ef0f8422e:2"> because that function invokes a callback function repeatedly, which is something that Promises are just not designed to do.</span></span>

<span key="7736f2bb53664e1cb8ff9436e5810275"><span offset-key="7736f2bb53664e1cb8ff9436e5810275:0">The Promise object defines a then() instance method. Instead of passing our callback function directly to </span>`getJSON()`<span offset-key="7736f2bb53664e1cb8ff9436e5810275:2">, we instead pass it to the then() method. When the HTTP response arrives, the body of that response is parsed as JSON, and the resulting parsed value is passed to the function that we passed to </span>`then()`<span offset-key="7736f2bb53664e1cb8ff9436e5810275:4">.</span></span>

<span key="6b3e87e127174b2ca80639748c4592dc"><span offset-key="6b3e87e127174b2ca80639748c4592dc:0">If you call the </span>`then()`<span offset-key="6b3e87e127174b2ca80639748c4592dc:2"> method of a Promise object multiple times, each of the functions you specify will be called when the promised computation is complete.</span></span>

<span key="45201cfe7dd941fa973ffdef5cb51f01"><span offset-key="45201cfe7dd941fa973ffdef5cb51f01:0">Unlike many event listeners, though, a Promise represents a single computation, and each function registered with then() will be invoked only once.</span></span>

## 

<span key="041878f13430449bbb6b7c0dbd63bb6f"><span offset-key="041878f13430449bbb6b7c0dbd63bb6f:0">HANDLING ERRORS WITH PROMISES</span></span>

<span key="1507e87243264ba5a9faf95882c34974"><span offset-key="1507e87243264ba5a9faf95882c34974:0">Asynchronous operations, particularly those that involve networking, can typically fail in a number of ways, and robust code has to be written to handle the errors that will inevitably occur.</span></span>

<span key="45250d2864b94b2c92f5354d12910065">`getJSON("/api/user/profile").then(displayUserProfile, handleProfileError);`</span>

<span key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c"><span offset-key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c:0">if </span>`getJSON()`<span offset-key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c:2"> runs normally, it passes its result to </span>`displayUserProfile()`<span offset-key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c:4">. If there is an error (the user is not logged in, the server is down, the user’s internet connection dropped, the request timed out, etc.), then </span>`getJSON()`<span offset-key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c:6"> passes an Error object to </span>`handleProfileError()`<span offset-key="6d21914705724b94b183d5db8fb4d51c:8">.</span></span>

<span key="990d87c4576c4f5c959d2cfafe17cde5"><span offset-key="990d87c4576c4f5c959d2cfafe17cde5:0">In practice, it is rare to see two functions passed to then(). There is a better and more idiomatic way of handling errors when working with Promises.</span></span>

<span key="36ef4e2a97964df3b50ba0fcbbbc6dc5"><span offset-key="36ef4e2a97964df3b50ba0fcbbbc6dc5:0">To understand it, first consider what happens if </span>`getJSON()`<span offset-key="36ef4e2a97964df3b50ba0fcbbbc6dc5:2"> completes normally but an error occurs in </span>`displayUserProfile()`<span offset-key="36ef4e2a97964df3b50ba0fcbbbc6dc5:4">. That callback function is invoked asynchronously when </span>`getJSON()`<span offset-key="36ef4e2a97964df3b50ba0fcbbbc6dc5:6"> returns, so it is also asynchronous and cannot meaningfully throw an exception (because there is no code on the call stack to handle it).</span></span>

1

<span key="1fc623ba98f34ca8baac4cb20e6178cb"><span offset-key="1fc623ba98f34ca8baac4cb20e6178cb:0">getJSON("/api/user/profile").then(displayUserProfile).catch(handleProfileError);</span></span>

## 

<span key="041dacd0f0f04f0d936a25fbfe8dc426"><span offset-key="041dacd0f0f04f0d936a25fbfe8dc426:0">Resolving Promises</span></span>

<span key="3556d030c5d14c70ac6f009191f9aeec"><span offset-key="3556d030c5d14c70ac6f009191f9aeec:0">In order for Promise chains to work usefully, the output of task 2 must become the input to task 3. The input to task 3 is the body of the URL that was fetched, parsed as a JSON object. But the return value of callback c1 is not a JSON object, but Promise p4 for that JSON object.</span></span>

<span key="09ee492c8b6c4a84b1520afc0549efde"><span offset-key="09ee492c8b6c4a84b1520afc0549efde:0">When p1 is fulfilled, c1 is invoked, and task 2 begins. And when p2 is fulfilled, c2 is invoked, and task 3 begins.</span></span>

<span key="5d745b095c1342dbab0e82bc6dc05b89"><span offset-key="5d745b095c1342dbab0e82bc6dc05b89:0">And when p2 is fulfilled, c2 is invoked, and task 3 begins. But just because task 2 begins when c1 is invoked,it does not mean that task 2 must end when c1 returns.</span></span>

<span key="04f83a12d8aa4d80a7a2cb644a3357c3"><span offset-key="04f83a12d8aa4d80a7a2cb644a3357c3:0">Promises are about managing asynchronous tasks, and if task 2 is asynchronous, then that task will not be complete by the time the callback returns.</span></span>

<span key="37bf86f8651c46fb8f72b2bcfff5c275"><span offset-key="37bf86f8651c46fb8f72b2bcfff5c275:0">When you pass a callback c to the </span>`then()`<span offset-key="37bf86f8651c46fb8f72b2bcfff5c275:2"> method, </span>`then()`<span offset-key="37bf86f8651c46fb8f72b2bcfff5c275:4"> returns a Promise p and arranges to asynchronously invoke c at some later time. The callback performs some computation and returns a value v. When the callback returns, p is resolved with the value v. When a Promise is resolved with a value that is not itself a Promise, it is immediately fulfilled with that value.</span></span>

<span key="9c9e1fb4025149b584cf60b26aff7283"><span offset-key="9c9e1fb4025149b584cf60b26aff7283:0">So if c returns a non-Promise, that return value becomes the value of p, p is fulfilled and we are done. But if the return value v is itself a Promise, then p is resolved but not yet fulfilled.</span></span>

<span key="6653db3988bf4f69b067d2ce8f9aaa04"><span offset-key="6653db3988bf4f69b067d2ce8f9aaa04:0">At this stage, p cannot settle until the Promise v settles. If v is fulfilled, then p will be fulfilled to the same value. If v is rejected, then p will be rejected for the same reason. This is what the “resolved” state of a Promise means</span></span>

<span key="73128c407f85439e835a97dad53baea0"><span offset-key="73128c407f85439e835a97dad53baea0:0">the Promise has become associated with, or “locked onto,” another Promise. We don’t know yet whether p will be fulfilled or rejected, but our callback c no longer has any control over that. p is “resolved” in the sense that its fate now depends entirely on what happens to Promise v.</span></span>

<span key="32278bbf1029497b8a03faabd7b904ba"><span offset-key="32278bbf1029497b8a03faabd7b904ba:0">Let’s bring this back to our URL-fetching example. When c1 returns p4, p2 is resolved. But being resolved is not the same as being fulfilled, so task 3 does not begin yet. When the full body of the HTTP response becomes available, then the .</span>`json()`<span offset-key="32278bbf1029497b8a03faabd7b904ba:2"> method can parse it and use that parsed value to fulfill p4. When p4 is fulfilled, p2 is automatically fulfilled as well, with the same parsed JSON value. At this point, the parsed JSON object is passed to c2, and task 3 begins.</span></span>

## 

<span key="5401036b97d843a68266d6c08f4c401c"><span offset-key="5401036b97d843a68266d6c08f4c401c:0">More on Promises and Errors</span></span>

<span key="66d447341af147959ba36a4f6fa5dbce"><span offset-key="66d447341af147959ba36a4f6fa5dbce:0">With synchronous code, if you leave out error-handling code, you’ll at least get an exception and a stack trace that you can use to figure out what is going wrong. With asynchronous code, unhandled exceptions will often go unreported, and errors can occur silently, making them much harder to debug. The good news is that the </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="66d447341af147959ba36a4f6fa5dbce:2"> method makes it easy to handle errors when working with Promises.</span></span>

<span key="776ef43275b347f2ae8fdd9a16c49cea"><span offset-key="776ef43275b347f2ae8fdd9a16c49cea:0">THE CATCH AND FINALLY METHODS</span></span>

<span key="e3b5a9e506ae43d1bd3a343552a02c2d"><span offset-key="e3b5a9e506ae43d1bd3a343552a02c2d:0">Normal exceptions don’t work with asynchronous code. The </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="e3b5a9e506ae43d1bd3a343552a02c2d:2"> method of Promises is an alternative that does work for asynchronous code.</span></span>

First, notice that the error object thrown with a regular, synchronous throw statement ends up being handled asynchronously with a </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="a74f4945846545c2a0785533307b5567:2"> method invocation in a Promise chain. This should make it clear why this shorthand method is preferred over passing a second argument to .</span>`then()`<span offset-key="a74f4945846545c2a0785533307b5567:4">, and also why it is so idiomatic to end Promise chains with a </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="a74f4945846545c2a0785533307b5567:6"> call.</span></span>

<span key="a3441546ab97424fa7f8df1dac9dd358"><span offset-key="a3441546ab97424fa7f8df1dac9dd358:0">it is also perfectly valid to use </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="a3441546ab97424fa7f8df1dac9dd358:2"> elsewhere in a Promise chain. If one of the stages in your Promise chain can fail with an error, and if the error is some kind of recoverable error that should not stop the rest of the chain from running, then you can insert a </span>`.catch()`<span offset-key="a3441546ab97424fa7f8df1dac9dd358:4"> call in the chain, resulting in code that might look like this:</span></span>

<span key="96476494e91d43db9472b8e04892e231"><span offset-key="96476494e91d43db9472b8e04892e231:0">Sometimes,we want to execute a number of asynchronous operations in parallel. The function </span>`Promise.all()`<span offset-key="96476494e91d43db9472b8e04892e231:2"> can do this. </span>`Promise.all()`<span offset-key="96476494e91d43db9472b8e04892e231:4"> takes an array of Promise objects as its input and returns a Promise.</span></span>

<span key="03ced588dffe40b0bcaa9cfb3b161e65"><span offset-key="03ced588dffe40b0bcaa9cfb3b161e65:0">The Promise returned by </span>`Promise.all()`<span offset-key="03ced588dffe40b0bcaa9cfb3b161e65:2"> rejects when any of the input Promises is rejected. This happens immediately upon the first rejection and can happen while other input Promises are still pending. In ES2020, </span>`Promise.allSettled()`<span offset-key="03ced588dffe40b0bcaa9cfb3b161e65:4"> takes an array of input Promises and returns a Promise, just like Promise.all() does. But </span>`Promise.allSettled()`<span offset-key="03ced588dffe40b0bcaa9cfb3b161e65:6"> never rejects the returned Promise, and it does not fulfill that Promise until all of the input Promises have settled. The Promise resolves to an array of objects, with one object for each input Promise. Each of these returned objects has a status property set to "fulfilled" or "rejected." If the status is "fulfilled", then the object will also have a value property that gives the fulfillment value. And if the status is "rejected", then the object will also have a reason property that gives the error or rejection value of the corresponding Promise.</span></span>

## 

<span key="15fb7eba865e40c588335dca8ab0e20f"><span offset-key="15fb7eba865e40c588335dca8ab0e20f:0">async and await</span></span>

<span key="70ea1934675d4d51b9770e9bcd19d0b4"><span offset-key="70ea1934675d4d51b9770e9bcd19d0b4:0">These new keywords dramatically simplify the use of Promises and allow us to write Promise-based, asynchronous code that looks like synchronous code that blocks while waiting for network responses or other asynchronous events.</span></span>

<span key="beae811db1a64ab7be08dac51084d668"><span offset-key="beae811db1a64ab7be08dac51084d668:0">Asynchronous code can’t return a value or throw an exception the way that regular synchronous code can. And this is why Promises are designed the way the are. The value of a fulfilled Promise is like the return value of a synchronous function. And the value of a rejected Promise is like a value thrown by a synchronous function.</span></span>

<span key="44a2373c12fe40f88752e6cc3eaae74d">`async`<span offset-key="44a2373c12fe40f88752e6cc3eaae74d:1"> and </span>`await`<span offset-key="44a2373c12fe40f88752e6cc3eaae74d:3"> take efficient, Promise-based code and hide the Promises so that your asynchronous code can be as easy to read and as easy to reason about as inefficient, blocking, synchronous code.</span></span>

<span key="fcf2e299c06344b28b3b1184131fde99"><span offset-key="fcf2e299c06344b28b3b1184131fde99:0">Given a Promise object p, the expression await p waits until p settles. If p fulfills, then the value of await p is the fulfillment value of p. On the other hand, if p is rejected, then the await p expression throws the rejection value of p.</span></span>

1

<span key="e85d4c229e3b4c46b60cd893d1be777e"><span offset-key="e85d4c229e3b4c46b60cd893d1be777e:0">let response = await fetch("/api/user/profile");</span></span>

2

<span key="4463e2600ae24245b45e9a6cb2501137"><span offset-key="4463e2600ae24245b45e9a6cb2501137:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="567c88d6bc1245dd9947135e435e2197"><span offset-key="567c88d6bc1245dd9947135e435e2197:0">let profile = await response.json();</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="bf1ec1cbe0924e2e86ea5b0aa05b9fe8"><span offset-key="bf1ec1cbe0924e2e86ea5b0aa05b9fe8:0">It is critical to understand right away that the </span>`await`<span offset-key="bf1ec1cbe0924e2e86ea5b0aa05b9fe8:2"> keyword does not cause your program to block and literally do nothing until the specified Promise settles. The code remains asynchronous, and the </span>`await`<span offset-key="bf1ec1cbe0924e2e86ea5b0aa05b9fe8:4"> simply disguises this fact. This means that any code that uses await is itself asynchronous.</span></span>

<span key="a6f9c482d18442fca9b75bca23510431"><span offset-key="a6f9c482d18442fca9b75bca23510431:0">Declaring a function </span>`async`<span offset-key="a6f9c482d18442fca9b75bca23510431:2"> means that the return value of the function will be a Promise even if no Promise-related code appears in the body of the function.</span></span>

<span key="05e4e705f764467cb4f7dbf7f95e6ac8"><span offset-key="05e4e705f764467cb4f7dbf7f95e6ac8:0">The </span>`getHighScore()`<span offset-key="05e4e705f764467cb4f7dbf7f95e6ac8:2"> function is declared </span>`async`<span offset-key="05e4e705f764467cb4f7dbf7f95e6ac8:4">, so it returns a Promise.
